notes: Apart from firing the event on window as other browsers do, Firefox also fires the event on the document object. See bug 1228802.

firefox.notes: Before version 62 this function returned null when called on a Window with no presentation (e.g. an iframe with display: none; set). Since 62 it returns a CSSStyleDeclaration object with length 0, containing empty strings (bug 1467722; also see bug 1471231 for further work).

firefox_android.notes: Before version 62 this function returned null when called on a Window with no presentation (e.g. an iframe with display: none; set). Since 62 it returns a CSSStyleDeclaration object with length 0, containing empty strings (bug 1467722; also see bug 1471231 for further work).

chrome.notes: A regular Event object is fired, rather than a HashChangeEvent object.

firefox.notes: This property was buggy and could give a wrong value before page load in certain circumstances, see bug 641188.

firefox_android.notes: This property was buggy and could give a wrong value before page load in certain circumstances, see bug 641188.

safari_ios.notes: This property returns the height of the visual viewport instead of the layout viewport. See this bug for details.

safari_ios.notes: This property returns the width of the visual viewport instead of the layout viewport. See this bug for details.

deno.notes: The key used for the Web Storage bucket is based on various factors. See the Deno manual.

firefox.notes: Before Firefox 57, single quotes contained in URLs were escaped when accessed via URL APIs. See bug 1386683.

firefox_android.notes: Before Firefox 57, single quotes contained in URLs were escaped when accessed via URL APIs. See bug 1386683.

firefox.notes: Before Firefox 86, if a new page from another domain is loaded into a tab, then window.name is not set to an empty string, which can allow some cross-site attacks. See bug 1685089 and bug 444222.

firefox_android.notes: Before Firefox 86, if a new page from another domain is loaded into a tab, then window.name is not set to an empty string, which can allow some cross-site attacks. See bug 1685089 and bug 444222.

chrome.notes: Before version 34, Chrome would fire a popstate event on page load.

firefox.notes: Firefox emits a popstate event on page load.

webview_android.notes: Before version 37, WebView would fire a popstate event on page load.

firefox.notes: Supports sending File and FileList objects between windows. This is only allowed if the recipient's principal is contained within the sender's principal for security reasons.

The message parameter is serialized using the structured clone algorithm. This means you can pass a broad variety of data objects safely to the destination window without having to serialize them yourself.
The message parameter must be a string.

firefox_android.notes: Supports sending File and FileList objects between windows. This is only allowed if the recipient's principal is contained within the sender's principal for security reasons.

The message parameter is serialized using the structured clone algorithm. This means you can pass a broad variety of data objects safely to the destination window without having to serialize them yourself.
The message parameter must be a string.

ie.notes: This function has no effect in the Modern UI/Metro version of Internet Explorer for Windows 8. It does not display a prompt to the user, and always returns undefined. It is not clear whether this is a bug or intended behavior. Desktop versions of IE do implement this function.

firefox.notes: Callback parameter is a DOMHighResTimestamp. This means ten microsecond precision and zero time as performance.now().
Callback parameter is a DOMTimestamp. This means millisecond precision and zero time as Date.now().
Could be called with no input parameters.

firefox.notes: Since Firefox 7, it's no longer possible for a web site to change the default size of a window in a browser if the window wasn't created by window.open or contains more than one tab. See here for more details.

Before Firefox 28, Gecko was using device pixels instead of CSS pixels; in other words, it was assuming a value of screenPixelsPerCSSPixel of 1 for any device.
